critique: This executive order establishes an advisory committee on small and minority business ownership. It aims to encourage subcontracting with eligible small businesses, particularly those owned by minorities or located in areas with high unemployment or low income. The order also emphasizes training, development, and upgrading of such businesses. It does not touch on immigration, national security, or civil liberties. It could be seen as slightly liberal due to its focus on minority businesses and social inclusion. It also involves government intervention in the economy to support these businesses. It does not expand executive power significantly, as it mainly establishes an advisory committee. It does not directly address federalism. The order promotes diversity and inclusion by focusing on minority-owned businesses.
